item.title: Listening to Fritz Kreisler – Liebesleid
item.dc:creator: pedro
item.description: The title, Love’s Sorrow, perfectly encapsulates its bittersweet character. There’s some sorrow running through the piece, yet it never feels tragic. Instead, it has a gentle, almost playful sadness, as if reminiscing on love that...
item.content:encoded:
The title, Love’s Sorrow, perfectly encapsulates its bittersweet character. There’s some sorrow running through the piece, yet it never feels tragic. Instead, it has a gentle, almost playful sadness, as if reminiscing on love that was once joyful but is now just a memory.

What stood out to me most was how expressive the violin line is. Kreisler’s writing makes full use of the instrument’s singing quality. The use of rubato is essential here, giving the piece a natural, speech-like fluidity. I particularly enjoyed the way the melody lingers on certain notes before moving forward, as if the violin itself is hesitating between sorrow and sweet recollection.

The accompaniment plays a crucial role in shaping the mood. The piano doesn’t just provide harmonic support, as it adds rhythmic movement and a subtle dance-like quality, almost like a slow waltz. This contrast between the flowing violin line and the steady, lilting accompaniment adds to the charm of the piece, making it feel intimate and conversational.

item.title: Listening to Gustav Holst – The Planets – IV. Jupiter
item.dc:creator: pedro
item.description: Listening to this piece was an interesting experience for me. I was amazed by how much ground the piece covers in just around seven minutes. It feels far longer than its actual duration. What stood...
item.content:encoded:
Listening to this piece was an interesting experience for me. I was amazed by how much ground the piece covers in just around seven minutes. It feels far longer than its actual duration. What stood out most was how cinematic it felt. I couldn’t help but associate the music with various film genres: moments of intense drama, romantic scenes, and even Western. This made me reflect on how music is so deeply connected with culture and personal memory. I found it fascinating that while I instinctively connected Jupiter to film scores, Holst composed it long before film music as we know it even existed. It made me wonder how much our listening experiences are shaped by what we’ve already heard, and how Holst’s music may have influenced the soundtracks that followed.

One of my favorite moments in the piece is when the beautiful D section emerges in the middle of all the energetic, almost chaotic sounds that come before it. The way the strings and horns gently introduce this melody feels like a breath of fresh air, and I loved how it gradually expanded to include the entire orchestra. This build-up was incredibly moving for me.

As I listened, I also noticed how well Holst balances contrasting moods and textures. The rhythmic drive and dynamic changes kept me on my toes, while the lyrical moments gave me time to reflect and immerse myself in the music’s beauty.

item.title: Research Task 3: Woodwind Extended Techniques
item.dc:creator: pedro
item.description: Extended flute techniques Fingering Techniques: Airflow Techniques: Embouchure and Articulation Techniques:
item.content:encoded:
Extended flute techniques

Fingering Techniques:

  • Alternate Fingerings/False Fingerings: These are fingerings not typically used, employed for technical reasons such as quick runs and trills, or to achieve a variation in tone. On the flute, these can be used as a special effect called flute harmonics, producing a hollow, more distant tone, often used in dreamy, programmatic scoring. These harmonics are notated with a circle over the note head. However, these fingerings tend to have weak projection and deficient intonation.
  • Multiphonic Tones: Certain fingerings, combined with careful voicing and embouchure control, can produce multiple tones simultaneously, somewhat like a double stop on a stringed instrument. The flute is particularly suited for this effect, capable of creating haunting combinations. These tones require careful preparation and are best used as slower, longer individual notes, not quickly in succession.
  • Key Clicks: This involves playing the instrument without breath, clicking the keys hard. A subtle pitch can be heard as the tube resonates. Deeper instruments might yield more pronounced results.

Airflow Techniques:

  • Air Effect: This is the opposite of key clicks, where the player simply blows into the pipe without forming an embouchure, resulting in a soft whooshing sound with elements of pitch. This effect can be varied by blowing through a closed or open pipe, adding soft consonants, or using fingered pitches with a bit of air. It is simpler to execute than normal playing.
  • Mutes: While mutes can be used on woodwinds by stuffing cloth into the end of the pipe, this is often disliked as a nuisance by orchestral players who can create a soft, muted tone without extra materials.
  • Circular Breathing: This technique allows a player to sustain airflow continuously by filling the cheeks with breath and quickly replenishing the lungs through the nose while expelling air from the mouth. It requires coordination between the player and orchestrator to ensure a suitable part is written and can be performed effectively.
  • Whistle Tones: Achieved by rotating the flute and altering the airflow across the embouchure hole, minimizing the mechanics of a vibrating air column. This creates a whistling sound, which can be difficult to control. Alternate fingerings may be used to secure the pitch, but there might be a tendency for the tone to flutter.

Embouchure and Articulation Techniques:

  • Glissando: A slide between pitches, often achieved by slightly raising or lowering pitch with the embouchure. Flutes can combine quick upward runs with embouchure changes to simulate wider glissandos.
  • Flutter Tonguing: The tongue is rippled against the palate or the glottis rolls against the back of the throat, creating a tremolo-like effect. This is marked with tremolo beams and “flz” to abbreviate “flatterzungen”.
  • Lip Attack: The lip is used to release air instead of the tongue, to define the start of soft notes or create a popping, bouncing series of notes.
  • Tongueless Attack/Niente Attack: This involves initiating airflow from the abdomen, making the attack seem to fade in from nothing. Flutes (especially lower register) and clarinets are best suited for “niente” attacks, where notes fade in and out of audibility. When a series of nearly niente notes is played in the chalumeau register they are called subtones.

item.title: Exercise 3: Woodwind in the Orchestra
item.dc:creator: pedro
item.description: In the opening of Debussy’s Prélude à l’après-midi d’un faune, the solo flute immediately establishes a character of simplicity. Its soft, expressive tone and ambiguous rhythmic flow evoke a mysterious quality, naturally linking the sound...
item.content:encoded:
In the opening of Debussy’s Prélude à l’après-midi d’un faune, the solo flute immediately establishes a character of simplicity. Its soft, expressive tone and ambiguous rhythmic flow evoke a mysterious quality, naturally linking the sound to mythology. The flute not only introduces the main idea of the piece but also, when it later appears alone in a low register against a subdued orchestral backdrop, it conveys a sense of rest.

Beethoven’s approach in the second movement of his Symphony No. 3 reveals the oboe as a deeply personal voice of mourning. While the orchestra provides a broad, dramatic funeral march, the oboe introduces an individual’s grief, almost lyrical. Its high-pitched, bright tone pierces through the heavy orchestration, creating a striking contrast. The oboe doesn’t just accompany the music; it provides emotional counterpoint, its plaintive cry standing out against the collective mourning of the full ensemble.

In The Swan of Tuonela, the cor anglais evokes a sense of solitude and the cold. Its melancholic yet elegant tone glides over the muted strings, much like the swan it represents. It blends with the cello in softer passages, creating a haunting dialogue. Sibelius’ orchestration ensures the cor anglais remains prominent, though it is occasionally masked by the orchestra, evoking a misty, dreamlike atmosphere. Against the darker orchestral backdrop, its bright, singing quality enhances the piece’s ethereal and sorrowful mood.

In Rachmaninoff’s Symphony No. 2, the clarinet introduces a more intimate, darker color against the metallic brightness of the strings. Its smooth, rounded melody provides a moment of introspection within the lush romantic orchestration. Where the strings might surge and swell, the clarinet offers a more subtle, contained emotional expression.

The bassoon’s opening solo in The Rite of Spring is strikingly neutral yet distinctive, played in its high register with soft dynamics, making it feel elusive and almost unidentifiable. The repetition of the motif establishes a rusticatmosphere before the orchestral chaos begins. Though the bassoon fades into a supporting role, its presence remains essential, doubling higher woodwinds and reinforcing the piece’s raw, untamed energy.

item.title: Listening to Antonín Dvořák – “Song to the Moon” from Rusalka
item.dc:creator: pedro
item.description: The piece is filled with an aching sense of longing, and from the very first notes, I felt completely drawn into its dreamlike atmosphere, pushed by the harp. It felt much like moonlight shimmering on...
item.content:encoded:
The piece is filled with an aching sense of longing, and from the very first notes, I felt completely drawn into its dreamlike atmosphere, pushed by the harp. It felt much like moonlight shimmering on water.

One thing that struck me was how the orchestration enhances the voice without overpowering it. The strings provide a delicate, flowing foundation, while the woodwinds play an especially expressive role. At times, they blend with the vocal line, doubling or supporting the melody to create a sense of warmth and intimacy. At other moments, they respond to the voice in a call-and-answer, almost as if the night itself is echoing Rusalka’s plea. This dialogue between the voice and the orchestra gives the aria a deeply organic feel, as if it’s breathing and evolving naturally.

I also loved how Dvořák used dynamics and phrasing to shape the emotional contour of the piece. The melody starts softly, almost hesitantly, then gradually grows, reaching soaring heights before retreating again into a hushed, intimate ending. The harp adds a subtle shimmer throughout, reinforcing the celestial, dreamlike quality of the music.

item.title: Research Task 2: Woodwind Through the Centuries
item.dc:creator: pedro
item.description: Different woodwind instrumentations have been used throughout history, with their development and usage often corresponding to specific eras and places. Early instruments were simple, such as whistles and basic flutes made from animal bones, dating...
item.content:encoded:
Different woodwind instrumentations have been used throughout history, with their development and usage often corresponding to specific eras and places. Early instruments were simple, such as whistles and basic flutes made from animal bones, dating back 43,000 years. These instruments likely served simple musical purposes, such as imitating bird calls, or playing simple melodies.

Over time, instrumentations evolved, with distinct instruments becoming popular in different regions:

  • Recorders were dominant in medieval Europe, particularly for indoor use due to their soft sound.
  • The transverse flute evolved from the Byzantine Empire and became popular in Europe by the Renaissance, offering greater volume and expressive control.
  • The Turkish Zorna, a folk instrument, was found across a wide area from Arabia to China and India.
  • The shawm, with a loud, penetrating tone, developed in Europe as an imitation of the recorder’s reed system.
  • The oboe and English horn emerged in the 17th century as refined versions of the shawm.
  • The dulcian, and later the bassoon, developed with a double-backed bore.
  • The clarinet developed in the 18th century with a single reed system and wider tone holes, gaining popularity in the late 1700s.

The type of music that suited each instrumentation varied. Early instruments were likely used for simple melodies and mimicry, while later instruments allowed for more complex musical styles.

  • The recorder, with its soft tone, was better suited for indoor use.
  • The transverse flute‘s increased capabilities allowed for more expressive playing and was common in Renaissance music.
  • The shawm’s loud tone was not suited to blend with other instruments.
  • The oboe and bassoon became essential parts of Baroque music, often used as supporting instruments, featured as soloists, and were standard members of the symphony orchestra by the time of Haydn.
  • The clarinet was incorporated into the symphony orchestra in the late 1700s by Haydn and Mozart, becoming a key part of the Classical period’s orchestral sound.

There are noticeable chronological changes in how these instruments were used. Early woodwind instruments were simpler, and their usage was likely for basic melodies. As instruments evolved, they became more complex and capable. The Baroque period saw the oboe and bassoon become regularly used as support instruments and featured soloists. By the Classical period, woodwinds were standard in orchestras, with the clarinet being incorporated later than the other main woodwind families. By the late 1700s, the woodwind section in orchestras had become standardised with flutes, oboes, clarinets, and bassoons forming the four fundamental families. Flutes were generally placed highest in the score, with oboes and clarinets positioned below them, and bassoons were placed lower still.

item.title: Exercise 1: Listening to Wind Quintets
item.dc:creator: pedro
item.description: Looking first at Janáček’s Mládí (1922), there’s a unique approach through his addition of bass clarinet to the standard wind quintet instrumentation. I’m struck by how this simple addition transforms the entire ensemble colour. His...
item.content:encoded:
Looking first at Janáček’s Mládí (1922), there’s a unique approach through his addition of bass clarinet to the standard wind quintet instrumentation. I’m struck by how this simple addition transforms the entire ensemble colour. His approach to blending is particularly notable in his strategic use of unison writing, especially between the bass clarinet and bassoon, which creates a warm, neutral sound that successfully avoids excessive reediness. What’s remarkable to me is how he manages to make these naturally reedy instruments sound almost string-like at times. He achieves contrast through varied instrumental groupings – for instance, combining horn and bass clarinet for ominous effects while using higher woodwinds (flute, oboe, clarinet) for lighter textures. Texturally, Janáček favours homophonic writing, particularly in the second movement, emphasizing clear melodic lines. He creates musical complexity through the density of voices rather than through contrapuntal writing.

Nielsen’s Wind Quintet (1922), takes what I would call a more “conversational” approach to instrumental relationships. When I listen to this piece, I can’t help but imagine five distinct personalities having an animated discussion. His writing carefully structures alternations between solo passages and tutti sections, with thoughtful distribution of thematic material across the ensemble. What impresses me is how he shows such sensitivity in pairing instruments effectively – creating duets between clarinet and bassoon, combining flute and oboe, and using horn and bassoon to provide foundational support. It’s as if he understood not just how each instrument sounds, but how they might best complement each other’s voices.

Ligeti’s Six Bagatelles (1953) represents what I find to be the most adventurous approach of the three works. There’s something almost theatrical about how he handles these instruments. His handling of instrumental relationships focuses heavily on exploiting extreme contrasts between instrumental registers, creating what he called distinct “colour worlds” that can shift rapidly. What fascinates me most is his deliberate use of timbral “mismatching” for artistic effect, as seen in the alternation between oboe and horn. His experimentation is evident in how he explores various instrumental combinations, contrasting high and low registers and using staccato articulation and varied dynamics to create interest.

item.title: Research Task 1: Secondary Woodwind Instruments
item.dc:creator: pedro
item.description: Flute Family Oboe Family Clarinet Family Saxophone Family Bassoon Family
item.content:encoded:
Flute Family

  • Instruments: Flute, Piccolo, Alto Flute, Bass Flute
  • Range: The piccolo extends the flute range up by an octave. The flute has three registers: low, medium, and high. The low register is weak in volume but rich in tone. The middle register is vibrant with good carrying power. The high register can be shrill and piercing.
  • Timbre: The low register of the flute is colourful, but the instrument can be masked by other instruments in this register. The piccolo’s lower octave has a “dry” quality. The flute’s extreme high register can be flute-like in soft dynamics.
  • Technique: Flute tone is produced by blowing air across a hole. The direction of air changes the octaves.
  • Effective Usage: Flutes are often featured playing the melody. The piccolo brightens and strengthens upper partials of an orchestration, but it can be used for solo passages. A unique use of the flute in its low register can be to carry the bass part when there are no other lower instruments.

Oboe Family

  • Instruments: Oboe, English Horn (Cor Anglais)
  • Range: The oboe has two registers, low and high. The lowest octave is the strongest. The English horn sounds a perfect 5th lower than written. The English horn is missing the lowest Bb, with its lowest note being the E below middle C.
  • Timbre: The oboe’s lowest notes can have a “honking” quality. The higher register is sweet but loses strength and can sound tight. The English horn has a warmer, fuller, and more mellow tone than the oboe. The lowest range of the English horn does not have the “honk” effect of the oboe.
  • Technique: The oboe uses a double reed. The oboe’s lower notes get louder, unlike the flute.
  • Effective Usage: Oboes produce a wide range of pitches, from haunting sounds to warm, smooth notes, making the sound memorable. The oboe is responsible for tuning the orchestra. The English horn is an alto oboe and has a lower pitch range. The oboe’s lowest register can be used to create a “honk”-ish quality.

Clarinet Family

  • Instruments: B♭ Clarinet, E♭ Clarinet, A Clarinet, Alto Clarinet, Bass Clarinet, Contrabass Clarinet
  • Range: The clarinet has four timbral registers: chalumeau (low), medium (throat tones and break), clarino, and extreme high. The E-flat clarinet plays higher notes, and the bass clarinet plays lower notes. A clarinet in A has an additional semitone down at the low end of the range.
  • Timbre: The chalumeau register is dark and mysterious. The medium register is brighter than the low register. The clarino register has a bright, trumpet-like quality. The extreme high notes can be flute-like in soft dynamics, and have a tendency towards shrillness.
  • Technique: Clarinets use a single reed. The clarinet is “in B♭”, meaning a written note sounds a whole-tone lower. There are many different kinds of clarinet.
  • Effective Usage: The clarinet is the band equivalent of the string section in an orchestra. Clarinets play both melodies and harmonies. The low register is capable of all dynamics, and rapid figurations in this register have a spectacular effect.

Saxophone Family

  • Instruments: Sopranino Saxophone, Soprano Saxophone, Alto Saxophone, Tenor Saxophone, Baritone Saxophone, Bass Saxophone
  • Range: The saxophone comes in a variety of sizes and ranges.
  • Timbre: The saxophone was designed to have a powerful and vocal sound with some of the projection of brass instruments.
  • Technique: The saxophone uses a single reed and is played like a woodwind, rather than a brass instrument. All saxophones share the same fingering system.
  • Effective Usage: The saxophone is primarily a band instrument, but it is becoming more present in orchestras. The saxophone has a wide spectrum of acceptable tones and is a forgiving instrument to play.

Bassoon Family

  • Instruments: Bassoon, Contrabassoon
  • Range: The bassoon has a large range, with the lowest octave being the most characteristically “double reed”. The contrabassoon sounds one octave lower than written.
  • Timbre: The bassoon has a tendency to loudness in its lowest register, and a tighter sound as it reaches the top of its range. The contrabassoon’s lowest notes are more “growly” than the bassoon. Above middle C, the bassoon has a powerful singing voice.
  • Technique: Bassoons use a double reed. Fingering in the very lowest part of the bassoon’s range can be challenging. The contrabassoon can be a little slower in responding to extremely rapid figurations.
  • Effective Usage: Bassoons usually play lower harmonies, but their hollow low notes can be featured in a melody. The bassoon is capable of a surprisingly light touch in its low register, with staccato notes akin to a cello’s pizzicato. The contrabassoon plays the lowest notes in the entire orchestra.

item.title: ORC Assignment 3: Arranging for String Orchestra
item.dc:creator: pedro
item.description: Stage 1 After discussing with my tutor I decided to orchestrate Debussy’s Prelude from the Suite Bergamasque. Section Measures Instrumentation & Texture Details/Character A Section mm. 1–19 First violins (melody), sparse use of double bass,...
item.content:encoded:
Stage 1

After discussing with my tutor I decided to orchestrate Debussy’s Prelude from the Suite Bergamasque.

Stage 2

Sent through submission form.

Stage 3

Reflection:

How successful do you feel your arrangement is?
I listened to different performances of the piece, but most closely to Maria João Pires’ performance of the piano version to understand the character of the piece and tried to remain faithful to that interpretation. For me, the biggest challenge was changing the work of such an iconic composer and understanding how much liberty I could take in orchestrating it. With that in mind, I feel that I was able to successfully convey the same delicate and intimate character in the A sections while also exploring new expressive possibilities in the B section. The addition of glissandos was particularly rewarding because it brought a texture and technique to the B section that isn’t available on the piano, allowing the string orchestra to provide a unique voice while respecting the original work.

How well do you think you used the instrumental resources available?
I think I created a balance between maintaining Debussy’s original mood and adding richness through orchestration. For example, the first violins carried the main melody in the A sections to preserve the lightness and simplicity of the piano version, while the sparing use of the double bass supported the ethereal mood. The violins and violas pairing in the coda added drama and power without overwhelming the piece’s subtle beauty.

How useful was the structural analysis in completing the arrangement?
The structural analysis was helpful in guiding my decisions and ensuring that my arrangement remained cohesive. By identifying the ternary form and understanding the transitions between sections, I could plan how to vary the orchestration while maintaining the overall flow. For example, recognizing that the A sections required a delicate, transparent texture helped me decide to a sparing instrumentation, while the contrasting nature of the B section encouraged me to experiment with glissandos. The analysis also helped me build toward the climax in the coda, where I layered the orchestra more fully.
